item.content:encoded: Elon Musk's Social Security claims are obviously wrong. Tens of millions of people over age 100 are NOT getting Social Security benefits. Here's the actual data: About 86,000 currently receive Social Security beneits and that figure includes 99-year-olds. Great chart from

item.content:encoded: Related to the forthcoming development research scandal, the fundamental problem (as in social psych) was this: THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS MAJOR CHANGES IN IMPORTANT THINGS FROM TINY INTERVENTIONS! *Every* paper making claims like this are wrong- you don't even need to read them.
item.author: Kevin A. Bryan

item.content:encoded:
You rarely see many economists agreeing so much, and with such degree of confidence.
The question: The US economy would benefit substantially by borrowing money to form a strategic crypto asset reserve fund?
The answers: https://t.co/IsJ1BDy9RN...
One of the worst policy ideas

item.content:encoded: Can we also keep in mind that while Zelenskyy like Churchill 1940-45 postponed elections, Trump in peacetime tried to overturn by violence an election he lost - and has since pardoned all the co-conspirators in his attempted coup?
item.author: David Frum

item.content:encoded: As mega-fraud $NKLA files Chapter 11 today after wiping out $30bn, let‚Äôs remember for a sec that Cowen‚Äôs ‚Äúresearch‚Äù in 2020 said that it would make $5.6bn in revenue in 2025. The gains from this SPAC was 39% of Cowen‚Äôs entire Q2 ‚Äò20 operating income! The Golden Age of Grift.
item.author: Wasteland Capital

item.content:encoded: Nadella: "there will be overbuild... I'm so excited to be a leaser. I build a lot, I lease a lot. I'm thrilled to be leasing lots of capacity in '27, '28. I look at the builds saying "This is fantastic". Only thing that's going to happen with all the builds is prices come down"

item.content:encoded: "First, margins have generally been increasing for most cohorts in the last 20 years. Second, the margin advantage of the most profitable companies has been steadily growing."

item.content:encoded:
Berkshire was an accident whose success is the culmination of initial conditions and hundreds of factors (within and outside Buffett‚Äôs control) that will never exist again.
Any comparison to a modern day company is hogwash.
item.author: Sidecar Investor

item.content:encoded: This is my #1 piece of advice for students wanting to study something in tech. I think economists took "revealed preference >>>> stated preference" as permission to not talk to smart non-economists in that area. A great Paul Krugman quote on this: https://t.co/atkUOnhYYT
item.author: John Horton

item.content:encoded: Perhaps $CVNA, despite insane gross margins, will actually make money one day selling cars, not just loans.
item.author: James Chanos

item.content:encoded: Dwarkesh: "Where is the value going to be created in AI?" Nadella: "Hyperscalers... Then after that, it becomes a little fuzzy. You could say, hey, there is a winner-take-all model- I just don't see it."
item.author: modest proposal

item.content:encoded: Nadella: "I think in models there is one dimension of, maybe there will be a few closed source, but there will definitely be an open source alternative, and the open-source alternative will actually make sure that the closed-source, winner-take-all is mitigated."
item.author: modest proposal

item.content:encoded: Nadella: "At the end of the day, speed of light is speed of light, so you can't have one data center in Texas and say, "I'm going to serve the world from there."
item.author: modest proposal

item.content:encoded: Another profitable company (Southwest Airlines) announces mass layoffs, in an effort to appease Wall Street. Firing workers *outside of a downturn* is a breach of the social compact. Workers should share in the upside when employers are profitable; instead, they are cut loose.
item.author: Hal Singer
